title: To Be a Contrarian, Start Small

sections.summary: This maxim addresses the difficulty of timing contrarian trades. Being a contrarian is profitable but dangerous. If you bet against the herd too early, you get trampled. Therefore, you must start with a small position (a 'feeler') and only scale up when the price action confirms your thesis.
sections.deep_dive: The market can remain irrational longer than you can remain solvent. A contrarian view is, by definition, fighting the current momentum. You need confirmation that the momentum is turning before you commit significant capital. The 'small start' buys you the time to be right.

sections.forecast_risks: Confirmation Bias. The risk is that you take a small position and then 'marry' it. You start looking for evidence that supports your contrarian view and ignoring the price action that contradicts it. Even a small position requires discipline to cut if the thesis is wrong.
sections.gms_conclusion: The pioneer gets the arrows. The settler gets the land. Don't be the first pioneer with all your capital.
